maize.description: Maize (corn) is Ghana's most important cereal crop, grown in all regions. It is a staple food used for banku, kenkey, and porridge. In Ghana, maize is typically planted during the major rainy season (April-June) and minor season (September-October).

growing_conditions.soil: Well-drained sandy loam soils with pH 5.5-7.0
growing_conditions.regions: All regions, with major production in Brong-Ahafo, Ashanti, and Eastern regions

diseases.name: Maize Lethal Necrosis
diseases.symptoms: Yellowing and drying of leaves from edges inward, stunted growth, premature plant death, poor grain filling
diseases.causes: Virus complex transmitted by aphids and leafhoppers
prevention: Use certified disease-free seeds like Obatanpa
Practice crop rotation with legumes
Control insect vectors with neem-based insecticides
Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
diseases.treatment: No cure once infected. Focus on prevention and use resistant varieties.

diseases.name: Northern Corn Leaf Blight
diseases.symptoms: Long, elliptical gray-green lesions (2-15cm) on leaves that turn tan, may have dark borders, severe defoliation
diseases.causes: Fungus Exserohilum turcicum, thrives in cool, humid conditions
prevention: Plant resistant varieties
Ensure proper spacing (75cm between rows, 25cm between plants)
Apply fungicides like copper-based products at first sign
Remove crop debris after harvest
diseases.treatment: Apply recommended fungicides early in disease development

pests.name: Stem Borers
pests.symptoms: Holes in stems, dead hearts, lodged plants
pests.control: Use neem extracts, plant early, use push-pull technology with desmodium

maize.fertilizer_recommendation: Apply 4 bags of NPK 15-15-15 at planting and 2 bags of Urea 3 weeks after planting per acre
maize.harvesting: Harvest when kernels are hard and moisture content is about 20-25%, typically 100-120 days after planting

rice.description: Rice is a major food crop in Ghana, cultivated in lowland (valley bottoms) and upland systems. Ghana aims to achieve rice self-sufficiency through various government initiatives.

growing_conditions.soil: Clay loam soils for lowland, well-drained soils for upland
growing_conditions.water: Continuous water supply for lowland rice
growing_conditions.regions: Northern, Volta, Ashanti, and Eastern regions

diseases.name: Rice Blast
diseases.symptoms: Diamond-shaped lesions with gray centers and dark brown borders on leaves, nodes, and panicles; neck rot causing whiteheads
diseases.causes: Fungus Pyricularia oryzae, favored by high humidity and nitrogen excess
prevention: Use resistant varieties like AGRON
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer
Ensure proper water management - alternate wetting and drying
Treat seeds with fungicides
diseases.treatment: Apply fungicides like tricyclazole or carbendazim at first symptoms

pests.name: Rice Stem Borers
pests.control: Use light traps, remove stubble, apply appropriate insecticides

rice.fertilizer_recommendation: Apply 2-3 bags of NPK 15-15-15 at planting and 2 bags of Urea at tillering stage per acre
rice.harvesting: Harvest when 80-85% of panicles turn yellow, about 120-150 days after planting

yam.description: Yam is a crucial tuber crop and cultural symbol in Ghana, particularly important in traditional ceremonies. Ghana is one of the world's largest yam producers.

growing_conditions.soil: Well-drained, deep, fertile sandy loam soils
growing_conditions.regions: Northern, Volta, Brong-Ahafo, and Eastern regions

diseases.name: Yam Anthracnose
diseases.symptoms: Dark brown to black spots on leaves and stems, leading to defoliation, stem dieback, and tuber rot in storage
diseases.causes: Fungus Colletotrichum gloeosporioides, spreads during rainy season
prevention: Use disease-free planting materials (setts)
Practice 2-3 year crop rotation with cereals
Stake plants properly for good air circulation
Apply fungicides like mancozeb preventively
diseases.treatment: Spray recommended fungicides at 7-10 day intervals during rainy periods

pests.name: Yam Beetles
pests.symptoms: Holes in tubers, reduced market value
pests.control: Use pheromone traps, practice crop rotation, apply appropriate insecticides to soil

yam.fertilizer_recommendation: Apply 2-3 bags of NPK 15-15-15 at planting and organic manure per acre
yam.harvesting: Harvest 8-10 months after planting when vines begin to dry

cassava.description: Cassava is a drought-tolerant root crop crucial for food security in Ghana. It is used for gari, fufu, and industrial starch production.

growing_conditions.regions: All regions, major production in Brong-Ahafo, Ashanti, and Volta regions

diseases.name: Cassava Mosaic Disease
diseases.symptoms: Yellow mosaic patterns on leaves, leaf distortion, stunted growth, reduced root yield
prevention: Use resistant varieties like Afisiafi
Plant disease-free stems
Control whitefly populations with insecticides
Rogue infected plants early
diseases.treatment: No cure. Remove and destroy infected plants to prevent spread.

pests.name: Cassava Green Mite
pests.symptoms: Yellow spots on leaves, leaf drop
pests.control: Use resistant varieties, apply recommended miticides

cassava.fertilizer_recommendation: Apply 2-3 bags of NPK 15-15-15 or NPK 12-12-17 per acre at planting
cassava.harvesting: Harvest 8-18 months after planting depending on variety and use

cocoa.description: Cocoa is Ghana's leading agricultural export, known worldwide for high quality. Ghana is the second largest cocoa producer globally.

growing_conditions.soil: Deep, well-drained loamy soils with pH 6.0-7.5
growing_conditions.regions: Western, Ashanti, Eastern, Central, Volta, and Brong-Ahafo regions

diseases.name: Black Pod Disease
diseases.symptoms: Small brown spots on pods that rapidly enlarge and turn black, white fungal growth on surface, complete pod rot
diseases.causes: Fungus Phytophthora palmivora, thrives in high humidity and rainfall
prevention: Regular pruning to maintain open canopy for air circulation
Remove and destroy infected pods regularly
Apply recommended fungicides like copper-based products
Weed control to reduce humidity around trees
diseases.treatment: Spray fungicides at 3-4 week intervals during rainy season, remove all infected pods

pests.name: Cocoa Mirids
pests.symptoms: Lesions on stems and pods, dieback, reduced yield
pests.control: Regular pruning, use recommended insecticides, maintain shade

cocoa.fertilizer_recommendation: Apply cocoa-specific fertilizer (0-22-18 + 9CaO + 7S) at 375g per tree twice yearly
cocoa.harvesting: Main crop: October-January, Light crop: June-August

soil_management: Test soil every 2-3 years to determine nutrient needs
Practice crop rotation to maintain soil fertility
Use organic manure to improve soil structure
Implement conservation tillage to reduce erosion
climate_resilience: Use drought-tolerant varieties during dry spells
Implement mulching to conserve soil moisture
Diversify crops to spread climate risks
post_harvest: Dry grains to 13% moisture content for storage
Use hermetic bags for grain storage
Store tubers in well-ventilated, cool conditions
Process perishables quickly to reduce losses
